Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course was a little rough-- the content itself is really interesting, but it was sometimes difficult to follow along with the professor. He taught the concepts at the speed that assumed people had a basic understanding of linguistics principles, which wasn't necessarily the case. While the information was sometimes interesting, it was difficult to remain engaged as the practicality of learning it all became a little puzzling at some points.

I learned so much in this class. I took it after Intro to Cognitive Science because I wanted to delve deeper into the language portion of that class, and my expectations were exceeded. I learned so much more about language than I ever even knew was possible to know, but lo and behold, it is! This class was absolutely fantastic.

I learned a lot about the cognitive side of language in this course (how language and the brain relate). More importantly, I learned a lot of linguisitics material, as each unit basically covered a small introduction to different sectors of linguisitics. Critical thinking with the course material learned was a skill gained due to how the exams tested not specific knowledge that was discussed in class directly, but had students apply the topics and general terms to a scenario for the most part.
Explored the way language functions and its relation to general cognitive systems.
Deep dive into the cognitive science of various aspects of language
Knowledge of the basics of linguistics and how such things are implemented cognitively in the brain. Certain studies were considered and analyzed critically as part of the course.

I learned about how speech is produced and perceived in the brain going in depth with topics such as recursion, numbers, sentence processing, language in unusual circumstances, phonology, syntax, color, space, and sex and gender.
I learned about language and many different studies about how we represent it in our brain.
The course mainly focuses on the basic building blocks of linguistics and their connection to cognition and the mind. Also a nice introduction to experimental linguistics.
-various intersections, theories, case studies & perspectives of cognitive science and linguistics
Practical skills for understanding more challenging cognitive science concepts. Plenty of interesting linguistics concepts too.
major theories of linguistics, some cognitive science, major experiments in the field
I learned about the basic assumptions of studies in linguistics, syntactic and semantic rules in symbolic models of languages, and alternative models such as connectionism.

I learned about the various aspects of language that are influenced by cognition and vice versa in areas like number, grammatical categories, sex/gender, etc. I also learned about the current research being done in the field of linguistics.
I learned about many different parts of linguistics, and how linguistics can be better understand under the broader lens of cognitive science.
Analytical skills, how the brain is similar to a computer.
I learned more about the way the brain might comprehends and produces language and how similar a lot of languages are in structure
I gained a basic knowledge of linguistics and a broader understanding of Cognitive Science. Every day there was new and interesting material!
I learned how the mind processes language.
Introductory knowledge of linguistics
I learned the basics of the field of linguistics, which has been extremely valuable.
Fundamentals for comparing and relating linguistics with the human mind in its physical and mental processes.
I learned how to view the human mind through the lens of linguistics.

I got an overview of the basic elements of linguistics study and saw areas in which I could take this study further. This course gave us the skills to interpret numerous experimental reports and to better manipulate the results of linguistics studies. I think that I became better at understanding how language is related to our minds as a whole and how language shapes many of our interactions outside of just pure language.
I learned a lot about linguistics, and some about how it is related to cognitive science. Id say this is more linguistics than cog sci

I understood much of human cognition with respect to language, with the best insights coming from how sentences and ideas are processed by the brain and how competing models try to analyze these behaviors. This taught me much critical thinking and analytical skills, which were well applied during examinations.
How to think about the minds capacity for language

how we produce language, process language, how languages differ, how we can learn about the ways in which we produce/process language from people with abnormal language, case studies on unique languages (ex. Piraha, Munduruku), universal grammar rules, how to diagram sentences and words, how human language is different from the languages of animals
understanding of linguistics as a facet of cognitive science.
A lot. I genuinely feel like I understand how the mind creates language and how language impacts our mind.
I learned the basics of cognitive science and linguistics, and their intersection.

I learned all about how we perceive languages, the debate over differences in cognition due to linguistic differences, basic linguistics (syntax, semantics, phonology, etc), and the connectionist (neural network) model.

I learned how our brain processes language. It was really insightful to see the different studies and the way of thinking that allows us to conclude: "this is how our brain must be processing this information."

I learned a lot about what it means to study cognitive science and even decided that I want to look into cognitive science as a potential major. I gained a lot of insight into how we communicate our thoughts through the most physical means without even realizing, the shapes our mouths make and how the physical production of sounds contributes to crafting our languages. I also learned a lot about possible hypotheses for how we handle the complexities of perceiving and delivering human language. I also realized the mechanisms and processes involved in language are impactful in many other categories.
I learned a lot about practices of cognitive science while also studying in depth a wide range of concepts in linguistics. In fact, this course persuaded me to change major to cognitive science.

I learned a lot about both the very technical and very broad aspects of linguistics. I also learned a lot about the cognitive science field in general, and got a small glimpse of the sheer breadth of the field. We began the course with linguistic basics, such as the techniques that linguists use to analyze different languages. Then, we delved into the way that language is reflected in the brain, and the way that different languages influence thoughts and developments (or vice versa). Then, we learned ways to model the way that language is processed in the brain, which involved delving into the realm of artificial intelligence and machine learning. Although these different topics appear disparate, they were very well-connected and related when presented in the class.

Although it is an intro course, I do not feel like the knowledge I had going into the course was enough to facilitate my understanding of the material. Professor Frank is a great lecturer and is very engaging, however, I wish more introductory material was given at the beginning of the course.

He tended to answer questions using large linguistic-based or computer-science-y terms that I rarely understood. Often times, if there were questions asked about homework/assignments, the answers were confusing and just prompted more questions. Also, it takes FOREVER for the assignments to be graded. We submitted one assignment BEFORE spring break and haven't received the grade yet (during Reading Week!).

No weaknesses, all strengths. Bob Frank is an amazing lecturer and all of the concepts are so well-explained. I never felt like I was not grasping something, and if I was, I know he and the TFs were extremely receptive. I will say we had two random reading responses at the very beginning of the semester that we then just never had again, so after the first few weeks I stopped doing the readings entirely but still didn't have a problem on the midterms or the final.

Strengths are how the notes and lecture basically discuss all that is needed to know on exams and most homework assignments, saving time for those who are busy from reading all of the extra material (which are emphasized as supplementary in class). Another strength is that Professor Frank is really passionate about the material and teaches it in an understandable manner, which makes both understand and note-taking simple in class. The powerpoints and modules on Canvas are very well put together as well. Improvements could be providing a little more time for assignments around midterm and finals season and posting the powerpoints for the class a little earlier than the day of class or the night before.
Really interesting material

The course is very interesting but seems to touch on a wide variety of subjects with little connections between them. Making topics transition smoothly from one to another giving some reason one might be interested in that would be advantageous.

The strength are the breath of topics covered. The weaknesses are the lectures and lecture slides. The lectures cover and incredible amount of information and the lecture slides often only explain part of the topic covered. Therefore, when you are studying for the exams, the lecture slides often prove unhelpful as not all of the information necessary is on them. Additionally, the lecture slides are never posted before class so you cannot follow along with them as Professor Frank is explaining the material, making it even more difficult to understand the topics covered.
Prof Frank was a great and enthusiastic lecturer. Course material was interesting at first, but the homeworks are unnecessarily long.
The professor is very engaging and passionate about the subject which really shows through the lectures. Maybe more details on the powerpoint slides.
The lectures at times feel a little long, but Professor Frank does a good job engaging the students. Very interesting and, at times, creative assignments. I had a lot of fun with those!

-material can be surface-level at times; I would have preferred to dive deeper on fewer topics
-the reading does not match the level of engagement with material in the lectures & exams
-but otherwise very informative & entertaining

Strengths- good and engaging lectures, fair tests and assignments

Weaknesses- the assignment where we had to install software- getting the experiment working took longer than the rest of the assignment. Also, I am skeptical of some of the research presented in the course, particularly experiments on babies or animals, but the findings of these studies were presented as facts.

This course is well organized, and has three non-cumulative exams that are relatively easy to study for. However, I think that the overarching topics and questions being posed in the lectures are not clear until the study guide for each exam is released. It would be much easier to learn the material if the lectures started with a quick plan of the elements we are going to cover, and ended with a summary of key points and questions.

The actual concepts covered in class are quite fascinating and can be applied to everyday life. Professor Frank is a fairly engaging lecturer who is genuinely interested in the topics at hand. However, the class was extremely disorganized and lectures could be dull due to abrupt transitions in concepts. The workload fluctuated wildly and assignments were not put on the syllabus and were thus assigned out of the blue. The TAs withdrew from the course right when we had a bunch of difficult assignments to work on.

Strengthsinteresting content, very nice and engaging professor, well-structured class
Weaknesseslectures can be tedious, and homework assignments are extremely unclear

Great course, great teacher, extremely interesting.

The notes could be improved. Meaning, powerpoints could have a bit more information. Sometimes if one didn't take notes for a part of the class, or if one missed something the teacher said, it was hard to read the powerpoints and understand what was going on.

I had a pretty hard time paying attention and following along with this class during lecture. I found that it felt a little all over the place, with some material coming across more clearly than others. This may seem like a lightly ridiculous suggestion, and I understand it may just be me that noticed this, but even little things like using a consistent format for the slideshows to bring some consistency to the way the information was presented would have helped me a lot. I think the changes in format added to the feeling that the course was somewhat disorganized.
I loved this course! I found it engaging, and just the right workload.
I found some of the material confusing and besides the five (rather time consuming and difficult) homework assignments, there was minimal engagement with the content of the lectures.
The course is very well taught, but it is sometimes hard to make connections between units.
The professor spoke to quickly and I wish the PowerPoints were more elaborative on explaining the point of each slide.

The course did not have TAs at the end, so I feel that I did not get the help I needed. There could have been clearer assignments laid out in the syllabus, as well as more feedback on progress within the class.

The strength of this course is its breadth. It had areas where we went really in depth but also areas where we were able to get an overview to give us a taste of many different areas of linguistics. The teaching is also a strength and Professor Frank always ensured that lectures were engaging. I think that the weakness of this class is that the lectures are too long. 50 minute lectures could help keep students focussed for the whole lecture.
Strengths: I found the lectures to be very interesting and engaging. The psets were long, but really interesting and hands on. The exams were not difficult
some topics felt glossed over

Strengths: Fun material, not too challenging, lively teaching atmosphere
Weaknesses: Lectures could in nature become dull - perhaps more problem-solving or hypothesis-based inquiries during lecture time
The strengths is the professors strong and charismatic lecture style. However he needs to organize reading modules, and maintain a clearer structure in lecture.
psets all felt worth my time, tests were pretty fair
strength: fantastic teaching

Strengths: very interesting (if you're interested in the topic to begin with); engaging professor; some added demonstrations to supplement presentation slides
Weaknesses: the homework was assigned randomly and was sometimes super confusing; although the slides are posted, it's often difficult to understand them if you miss any lecture
Professor Frank is incredibly passionate about what he teaches, which made lectures interesting and memorable.
There is a lot of material packed into each lecture and it was presented really quickly. Each hour and 15 minute lecture felt like a sprint, which made it a bit exhausting to keep up for that long.

This class was not too demanding, covered very course material, and was well-taught. My only complaint was that classes were long and late in the afternoon, which isn't really something that can be improved.

Professor Frank did a wonderful job with engaging lectures. I learned a lot about linguistics and our mind's perception of language, and I liked the structure of the class with problem sets and three equally weighted exams (all very fair). He made the material challenging and went pretty in-depth at some points into things like neural networks and syllable typology, which I really appreciated (didn't feel just like a surface-level class).
The homework assignments were very confusing. I feel that they could have been explained better.

strengths: ROBERT FRANK, forced me to think about the way I communicate, unique, surprising, made me realize things I do every day that I never actually think about, lecture-based exams, lively lecture, grading policy, fair work load, a lot of application, very helpful teaching fellow
weaknesses: if you miss lecture it is hard to fully understand the lecture slides (and no textbook reading to back it up), dense information on exams (but manageable compared to some Yale courses I've taken), would possibly be better as a 50-minute lecture on 3 days a week because lectures often felt long and the time of day caused me to fall asleep on occasion
Section discussions would have greatly enriched my engagement with course material.

The material of this class was excellently presented and overall, it was very engaging. At times, some of the technical bits were very hard to follow, but the homework assignments were good at reinforcing these ideas and walking through the teaching processes again. That being said, the homework assignments, while infrequent, were all incredibly long and very tedious.
I would recommend this course to a student that is genuinely interested in linguistics or cognitive science.
Unless you are a linguistics major or cog sci major and need it, i probably wouldn't recommend it.

I definitely would. This class was fabulous. It completely changed my perspective on language and life, and is so applicable to everyday life just because we use language every day. Now I find myself connecting real world occurrences to things I've learned in class, which is not something I can say for most of the classes I've taken. I genuinely feel like a more intelligent person after having finished this course.

I would most definitely recommend this course to other students, especially if they are interested in languages and learning about how language in the brain works. I enjoyed the lectures and learning more about the material presented. The course was well-tailored to student learning and has been one of my favorite classes at Yale.
Great intro cogsci class. Professor is funny and engaging.
I would. I thought it was really interesting.
Yes, the professor is wonderful and we learn a lot. The prof and TFs are very conscious of making sure every student is performing well in the course.

I would not recommend this course to someone else. I thought that the teaching style of Professor Frank did not facilitate an easy understanding of the material being taught and that some of the material taught was tedious to learn and not useful in later life. Upon turning in a problem set, we had to wait weeks or even a month to get our grade back and often times it was with little explanation of why we received the grade we did.

Yes, if they are interested in learning more about language, this is a good introduction to linguistics with a mix of cognitive science. The lectures are cool and the assignments are also fun because you learn a lot.

This is a relatively interesting course--perfect for the linguistics requirement for the Cognitive Science major. The material is much heavier on the linguistics side of things than on the cognitive science side of things.
Yes! The course makes you think a lot more about how you use your language and what the implications are. Very interesting!
Yes, very interesting course.

If the first few lectures interest you then sure! i took it credit D and had to miss a few classes for grad school interviews and found it easy to catch up. Not a mind-blowing class but well taught and a relatively low workload.

Not really. This class wasn't particularly interesting and I'm not sure what I got out of it. I do think that the professor's teaching style is oriented towards those who take a more computational approach to learning information, so you might appreciate the class more than I did if you have a STEM background.

I would recommend this course with major caveats. The actual concepts covered in the course are quite fascinating and I felt like I came away with a good basic foundation of linguistics after taking this class. Nevertheless, the course was very disorganized which made my experience negative. The five homework assignments we were expected to complete did not have dates listed in the syllabus and were thus assigned out of the blue at the most inconvenient times with a week to do. In addition, the assignments were extremely difficult and could essentially only be completed with the guidance of TAs, but it just so happened that both TAs withdrew from the course in the middle of the semester so it became even more difficult to do the homeworks. Lectures were generally confusing and seemed out of order. We also fell behind about a week so both midterms were pushed back. If the course structure were changed drastically, I would wholeheartedly recommend the course.

If someone is particularly interested in how cognitive science concepts apply to linguistics, this is a good course to take. However, otherwise, I'd probably recommend other introductory cognitive science classes over this onewhile there are certainly great things about this class, there are also considerable downsides (the homework assignments are confusing and lectures can sometimes go on for a very long time and/or be overly detailed).
Yes! Such an interesting way to gain insight on what we are.
No
Yes! This course was fun, interesting, and engaging!
Yes, but ideally the prof/TF team will be more engaged and available in the future.
Yes! This course got me interested in linguistics as a whole and I learned a ton. It is very interesting to take if you dont have previous exposure to linguistics.
I would recommend this course if the student is passionate about linguistics.
If you enjoy linguistics, take this class. Perhaps next time there will be more help once the TAs come back.
Yes, I would recommend this to students interested in trying out linguistics.
Yes. I thought the material was fascinating, the professor was a great lecturer, I enjoyed the variety of the psets
I would definitely recommend this course. Not only is it engaging and fun, but the content is meaningful and illuminates our own everyday behaviors from a scientific standpoint.
Yes, but with caveats

Yes! I just took this class for fun- it's totally unrelated to my major. I thought it was fascinating and a learned a lot. The work was enough to be thorough but not excessive. I think anybody who has any interest in the way our brains work to create and understand language should take this course!
yes. great teaching. engaging intro to linguistics.
As long as they're interested in language and the mind, I'd say yes.

If you are interested in how the brain processes linguistics and the more technical side of linguistics (trees, phonemes, etc). I was more interested in learning about cultural differences and how that impacts linguistics (linguistics in a sociology sense), which, I think, was one reason I did not enjoy this course as much as I wanted to.

I would recommend this to another student. It's a good introduction to many linguistic concepts, and I definitely learned a lot of things I had never seen before.  It moves quickly and the syllabus wasn't very organized as far as knowing ahead of time when things are due, so if you learn slowly you may want to seek extra support in this course or you may have to work a little extra hard.
Absolutely.
Yes, if you're interested in cognitive science and/or linguistics; it's a great elective and I feel like I learned a lot. Professor Frank is great.

If you are interested in linguistics and cognitive science, then yes this course is super great. If you're interested in the kind of thinking you do in cog sci classes, then yes this course is a pretty good representation.

I definitely would (and already have) recommend this course to other students. It doesn't have a crippling workload, and it is an interesting area of study that helped me realize a lot about human communication and cognition involved with that. Plus, the professor is great. This was one of my favorite courses I've taken at Yale, and I think it was taught very well.
Yes! Very cool course that may aid in the discovery of a passion for cognitive science.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the science of language, and who has not taken a linguistic course before.

Yes - taking this class made me realize that I wanted to major in cognitive science. No matter whether a student is interested in linguistics or not, this class is an excellent introduction to the major and does a great job of showing how broad it is. There really is a place in cognitive science for everyone.
